title: Ted Hill (Australian communist)
text:
Edward Fowler Hill (23 April 1915 – 1 February 1988) was an <a href="Australian">Australian</a> barrister, lawyer and <a href="Communism">communist</a> activist. He was chairman of the <a href="Communist%20Party%20of%20Australia%20%28Marxist%E2%80%93Leninist%29">Communist Party of Australia (Marxist–Leninist)</a> (CPA M-L) from 1964 to 1986.
History.
Hill was born on 23 April 1915 in <a href="Mildura%2C%20Victoria">Mildura, Victoria</a> to James and Alice Hill. He attended school at Hamilton High School, where his father was head teacher. After leaving school he worked as a clerk for <a href="Bill%20Slater%20%28politician%29">Bill Slater</a> a local <a href="barrister">barrister</a> who was also the local <a href="Australian%20Labor%20Party">Labor</a> Member of Parliament. In 1933 he moved to Melbourne to study law at the <a href="University%20of%20Melbourne">University of Melbourne</a>. Despite being awarded for his academic knowledge he did not finish his legal degree until 1981. It was during his time at the university that he joined the <a href="Communist%20Party%20of%20Australia">Communist Party of Australia</a> (CPA).
He was admitted to practice as a barrister and solicitor in 1938 and soon became well known as the CPA's leading legal figure, defending the party and its members in several well-known trials. In 1951 he advised <a href="Frank%20Hardy">Frank Hardy</a> in his prosecution for <a href="criminal%20libel">criminal libel</a> over his novel "<a href="Power%20Without%20Glory">Power Without Glory</a>". Hill also represented the CPA before the 1947 <a href="Royal%20Commission">Royal Commission</a> into Communism and the 1954 Royal Commission into alleged <a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviet</a> <a href="espionage">espionage</a> in Australia (see <a href="Petrov%20Affair">Petrov Affair</a>).
Split.
In the 1950s, Hill was Victorian State Secretary of the CPA. When the <a href="Sino-Soviet%20split">Sino-Soviet split</a> developed in the early 1960s, Hill supported the position of the <a href="Communist%20Party%20of%20China">Communist Party of China</a>, while the CPA majority, led by National Secretary <a href="Laurie%20Aarons">Lance Sharkey</a> supported the Soviet Union. Hill was expelled from the CPA in 1963 and in March 1964 formed the Communist Party of Australia (Marxist–Leninist) (CPA(ML)), taking many militant members from the Victorian CPA with him. Among ordinary Australian voters, the attraction of Hill's party was negligible.
Hill fully supported the "line" of the Chinese Communists until <a href="Mao%20Zedong">Mao Zedong</a>'s death in 1976, but after the 1972 change in Chinese policy away from world revolution and towards an alliance with the <a href="United%20States">United States</a>, the CPA(ML) lost many of its adherents, particularly among radical students. Hill traveled to Democratic Kampuchea and met with Pol Pot. After the rise of <a href="Deng%20Xiaoping">Deng Xiaoping</a> in China the CPA(ML) no longer supported Chinese policies, and became a supporter of "Australian independence." This led to a split in the CPA(ML) in 1978.
Despite his prominence as a Communist, Hill was able to pursue a long and distinguished legal career, as one of the best known and highly regarded <a href="workers%20compensation">workers compensation</a> lawyers in Australia. He was widely praised by trade unions, judges and other lawyers, most of whom did not share his political views, on his death in 1988.
